qas.question: Who attempted to enact measures of football reform?

answers.text: the presidents of Harvard, Yale, and Princeton

qas.question: What did the rebellion to the new football measures start?

plausible_answers.text: the presidents of Harvard, Yale, and Princeton

qas.question: Who attempted to enact measures of soccer reform?
What did the rebellion to the old football measures start?
Who was vice president of Yale during the rebellion?
Who represented Harvard after the rule changing debates?
Who represented Princeton before the rule changing discussions?

context: In 1909–10, football faced a crisis resulting from the failure of the previous reforms of 1905–06 to solve the problem of serious injuries. There was a mood of alarm and mistrust, and, while the crisis was developing, <a0_0><b5_0>the presidents of Harvard, Yale, and Princeton<b5_0/><a0_0/> developed a project to reform the sport and forestall possible radical changes forced by government upon the sport. President <a2_0><b7_0>Arthur Hadley<b7_0/><a2_0/> of Yale, <a3_0><b8_0>A. Lawrence Lowell<b8_0/><a3_0/> of Harvard, and <a4_0><b9_0>Woodrow Wilson<b9_0/><a4_0/> of Princeton worked to develop moderate changes to reduce injuries. Their attempts, however, were reduced by rebellion against the rules committee and formation of the <a1_0><b6_0>Intercollegiate Athletic Association<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The big three had tried to operate independently of the majority, but changes did reduce injuries.
